answers.answer: Diabetes can be a side effect of some medications, most generally atypical antipsychotics. But regardless of where its from, if you have diabetes you have to take eating a healthy diet very seriously. Your psychiatrist should refer you to a nutritionist for that. Medications can make people lose or gain weight (the Clonidine I am on makes me want to overeat for example) but when people are manic they tend to eat more and lose weight because they are speeded up and when depressed people can either eat less as they are too depressed to eat or sometimes eat more as a form of self medication. I wouldn't want to post any specifics about healthy eating other than eating breakfast is an absolute neccessity. Three healthy meals a day and other basics. But if you have diabetes your psychiatrist might want you to be on a very specific diet to control sugar intake and a doctor should advise you more of that.

I think when one is depressed, in a mixed state, or manic they are not in a position to make good daily choices.  However, having said that, many people Bipolar or not, make bad choices.  Many people skip breakfast, eat a small lunch and then overeat at dinner.

Wh en  you are bi polar it does affect how we eat. I have learend to eat 6 small meals a day and no sugar, caffiene or sodas I have lost 46 pounds this way and I feel so much better. This has been difficult as I am on zyprexa and celexa. these 2 are nototious for weight gain.I wont stop taking them though because I have done so well on this combo.I also lift weights and take a walk everyday.I am at a plateau right now with my weight loss ( just cam back from Florida vacation) So I gained a few pounds.Concentrate on small portions of protien and lots of fruits and veggies.I keep lots of these on hand to snack on.Love Venora

actually I got the diabetes before I started taking bipolar medsI have learned a lot about health and nutrition from having diabetes...I take seriquil I think it might cause you to eat more I noticed I lost weight whenI lowered my dosage....all I know is that I think I may have been using food as a crutchdurring certain peroids in time I started over eating beofore I got my bipolar meds straight due to stress and I gained 50 lbs in one year....that isn't the only time my weight has changed when going through symptoms of bipolarI also noticed that I eat more when I'm depressed and less when I am manicthis could be a contributing factor

Difficult question to answer as Marfan's people are notorious for looking scrawny.  I do tend to avoid certain foods, tastes and textures all together as I cant stomach them and I don't eat a lot at all.  I won't really know wether it is due to the HCTD or the BP.I am at a constant weight of approx 69-70kg's since high school.
When you eat high carbohydrate foods it boosts the seratonin level in your body giving you almost like a 'high' feeling.Just a lil FYI.

I work with patients with diabetes every day. Diabetes type 2 is caused by environment and genetics. (For example over eating mixed with family history of type 2 puts you at high risk.) Type 1 diabetes is an autoimmune deficiency. As for either type of diabetes if you are having trouble with your nutrition you should see a Certified Diabetes Educator. If you have type 1 you should have an endocrinologist. Having a good diabetes care team and the right treatment along with healthy diet is what will keep you in control of your blood glucose.Also, being bipolar and having diabetes will be trouble. Stress in itself causes your blood sugar to rise.Personally I have trouble eating both ways. If I am high anxiety I can't eat. Then when the anxiety goes away I eat too much. I also have a lot of issues with food, too much to go into here. I don't know if it the BP or something else.

I too have issues with food.  I tend to overeat when I am stressed and undereat (is that a word? lol) when I am manic.  Lately I have been on the stressed and depressed side so I overeat.  I know I do it, but I can't seem to stop!  I have gained weight recently and have been to depressed to exercise.  Gaining weight makes me even more depressed!  I am also diabetic so what I eat effects my blood sugar as well.So, to answer your question, yes I think bp has a lot to do with how we eat.

I tend to have the same eating issues as theguts. I overeat when I'm depressed. One time, I gained 40 lbs. in under five months during a depressed period. Unfortunately, though mania lowers my appetite, it doesn't help me lose weight.
when im depressed i gain weightwhen im manic i lose weight

I have had depression for awhile, and exercising definately helps.  On days with high anxiety or depression it sometimes takes a few tries to even make it out of the door to the gym.  For me, i might change my outfit 2 or 3 times before I successfully actually WALK through the door, spend an hour in the mirror fussing or walk in circles around the house in a daze.  Either way, once I make it out that door to the gym and start exercising, my heart rate elevates and I start sweating...I feel better.Its really a great remedy.  I know its not easy to get there, but it might encourage healthy eating too as you wont want to waste all the work you just did at the gym!

When I'm manic I lose weight, but I''m not prone to becoming overweight when I'm depressed. I think manic or depressed my eating habits suck.  Sometimes I'm just not that interested in food. I think that people with mental illness in general have poor eating habits and also poor health habits.

I agree. I think it can be hard for us to take care of ourselves. I have noticed that in the patients we see a high number of them also have depression. I wonder if it is depression due to their diabetes diagnosis and weight or depression due to genetics.I don't lose very much weight and then I gain it back. Being heavy doesn't help my self-esteem. I have a lot of anxiety when I exercise. It is one of those things I need to work on.
